EVALUATION
In order to determine the effectiveness of television as a medium of instruction, it is
important that careful evaluation be a part of every aspect of the project. It was felt
that this evaluation should not be rigidly pre-determined but grow out of the experiences
of the first year's work in orienting teachers and trying out ways of working with this
new medium. As a result of the summer workshop experience and the actual participation
in developing televised instruction, data are now being collected to provide a basis for
evaluating along such lines a;
1 . Surveying and summarizing community reactions to the use of the television medium
as judged by pupils and parents
2. Registering the desire or the lack of desire of regular classroom teachers to function
as television teachers
3. Studying the success of pupils in large classes under the leadership of capable class¬
room teachers
4. Studying the achievements of pupils of varying ability and contrasting the results with
previous records and with other pupils not participating in the television project
5. Studying the results of standardized tests in subject matter areas as well as those tests
that are constructed by television teachers
6. Reassigning teachers in such a way as to enable them to make their greatest contri¬
bution to the teaching process by performing those phases of the procedure for which
they are best suited because of interest, training and experience
7. Recording the special ways in which the learning skills of questioning, observing,
listening, assigning, etc. are employed
